title: Subtlety and Simplicity
subtitle: Shang Dynatsty
content: During the Shang Dynasty, there were no artificial decorative colors used in bronzeware. Bronze vessels displayed only the natural color of the bronze alloy, which ranged from yellowish-brown to grey-green depending on the copper, tin, and lead content.

title: Limited Use of Color
subtitle: Western Zhou Dynasty
content:
In the Western Zhou Dynasty, there was very limited use of color. Bronze still showed its natural metallic tone.

In rare cases, traces of red pigment, specifically cinnabar, have been found, indicating the earliest experiments with painted decoration.

title: Inlay and Painting
subtitle: Eastern Zhou Dynasty
content:
The Eastern Zhou Dynasty saw significant development in decorative colors.

The introduction and widespread use of inlay techniques became prominent, with gold, silver, and copper inlaid into carved grooves, creating strong color contrasts—gold/yellow, silver/white, and copper/red.

Additionally, mineral pigments such as cinnabar red, green, and blue were used to highlight certain areas.

Some bronzes combined both inlay and painting techniques for multicolored effects.

title: Peak of Color Decoration
subtitle: Qin and Han Dynasties
content:
The Qin and Han Dynasties marked the peak of colored decoration in Chinese bronzes. Advanced gilding techniques, such as mercury gilding, were used to cover surfaces with a layer of gold, resulting in a brilliant golden appearance.

The continued use of gold and silver inlays often formed complex patterns.

There was also systematic use of mineral pigments for painted decoration, sometimes layered over gilded or inlaid surfaces to create multi-layered color effects.
